title: How to Customize Your Windows Folder & Program Icons

steps.title: Open Paint.
steps.content: Open Paint. Paint is a free drawing and image editing software that comes pre-installed on all Windows computers. If you prefer, you can use any image editor or drawing program that you like. However, the steps in this article will be for Microsoft Paint, so if you use a different program, the steps may not line up exactly. This section of the article teaches you how to draw a custom icon. If you want to use a photo or image you already have as an icon, jump to the next part .

steps.title: Change the size of your canvas.
steps.content: Change the size of your canvas. Icons are always square. If you use a rectangular canvas, the final icon will be squished. Size doesn't matter at this point, but make sure the canvas is bigger than 100 pixels on each side. To change your canvas size, follow these steps: Windows 10: Click on the Home tab, then click Resize . Change the vertical and horizontal to the same number (any number is okay, as long as it's bigger than 100). Windows 11: Click File > Image properties and change the width and height to the same number (any number is okay, as long as it's bigger than 100).

steps.title: Draw your icon.
steps.content: Draw your icon. Use the tools at the top of the window to draw your icon. You can change your brush size, shape, and color. You can also add shapes like squares, circles, triangles, arrows, and more. If you want, you can turn on gridlines to make it easier to create a symmetrical icon. To do this, follow these steps: Windows 10: Go to the View tab and check Gridlines . Windows 11: Click View and choose Gridlines .

steps.title: Add transparency with layers (Windows 11 only).
steps.content: Add transparency with layers (Windows 11 only). In the Windows 11 version of Paint, you can now add layers to create transparent backgrounds. On Windows 10, you cannot do this, so your icon must always have a solid background color. Click Layers in the top bar. A sidebar will appear showing the layers in your image. You automatically start with one layer, as well as a background layer (which is at the bottom of the sidebar). Hover the background layer and click the eye icon to disable the background. You will see that your canvas is now a gray checkerboard. When you save the image, any part of the canvas that shows the gray checkerboard will be transparent.

steps.title: Save your icon.
steps.content: Save your icon. Once you're finished, click File > Save as and save your image as either a JPG/JPEG or PNG. If part of your image is transparent, you must save it as a PNG. If you save it as a JPG/JPEG, the transparent parts will turn white. Once you've saved your image, jump ahead to learn how to convert your image to an ICO file .

steps.title: Open Paint.
steps.content: Open Paint. Paint is a free drawing and image editing software that comes pre-installed on all Windows computers. If you prefer, you can use any image editor or drawing program that you like. However, the steps in this article will be for Microsoft Paint, so if you use a different program, the steps may not line up exactly. This section of the article teaches you how to use a photo or image as an icon. If you want to draw your own icon, jump back up to the first part .

steps.title: Press Ctrl+O to open an image or photo.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + O to open an image or photo. Choose the image or photo you want to turn into an icon and open it in Paint.

steps.title: Crop the image into a square.
steps.content: Crop the image into a square. You can crop the image into any size square, as long as it's bigger than 100 pixels on each side. To do this, follow these steps: Click the selection button in the upper-left corner of the screen. It looks like a box with a dashed line. Press and hold ⇧ Shift while clicking and dragging your mouse over the part of the image you want in the icon. This will ensure the selection box stays a square. Release your mouse button and then ⇧ Shift to finish making your selection. Click the crop button in the top bar. It's just to the right of the Selection button, and it looks like two intersecting right angles. If you don't like how the crop looks, press Ctrl + Z to go back one step, then repeat the steps above until you have a crop that you like.

steps.title: Save your icon.
steps.content: Save your icon. Once you're finished, click File > Save as and save your image as either a JPG/JPEG or PNG.

steps.title: Go to https://icoconvert.com in a web browser.
steps.content: Go to https://icoconvert.com in a web browser. In order for your computer to use your custom icon as an icon, it must be in the ICO image format. ICO Convert is a website that will convert PNG and JPG/JPEG images to ICO format for free. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Choose File under "Step 1."
steps.content: Click Choose File under "Step 1." When the dialog box pops up, navigate to the icon you just created and click Open .

steps.title: Click Upload.
steps.content: Click Upload . Your image will now appear on the page under the "Step 2" heading. If you want, you can crop your icon further on the ICO Convert site under "Step 2." You can also choose an icon style under "Step 3" to change the icon's shape and add a border and/or drop shadow. These two steps are optional, however, and you can skip them if you want to just convert your icon as-is.

steps.title: Choose the ICO option under Step 4.
steps.content: Choose the ICO option under Step 4. Make sure the circle next to "ICO for Windows 10, Windows 11, 7 and 8" is selected under the "Step 4" heading.

steps.title: Click Convert ICO.
steps.content: Click Convert ICO . ICO Convert will automatically convert your image to the ICO format.

steps.title: Click Download your icon(s).
steps.content: Click Download your icon(s) . Your new ICO file will be downloaded. If your browser doesn't ask where to save the file, it will most likely be saved to your Downloads folder.

steps.title: Navigate to the desired folder or program in File Explorer.
steps.content: Navigate to the desired folder or program in File Explorer. Alternatively, if the folder or program that you want to change the icon of is on your desktop, you can minimize all open windows to view your desktop instead.

steps.title: Right-click the folder/program and click Properties.
steps.content: Right-click the folder/program and click Properties . In Windows 10, this option is near the bottom of the contextual menu. In Windows 11, it's near the middle of the contextual menu.

steps.title: Click on Customize for Shortcut.
steps.content: Click on Customize for Shortcut . If you're changing a folder's icon, choose Customize . If you're changing the icon of a program, click Shortcut (but this tab will likely be open by default when you go to Properties ).

steps.title: Click Change Icon….
steps.content: Click Change Icon… . For both folders and programs, this button is at the bottom of their respective tabs.

steps.title: Click Browse….
steps.content: Click Browse… . Navigate to the location where your ICO file was saved.

steps.title: Click on your ICO file.
steps.content: Click on your ICO file. It will now appear as an option you can select for your folder or program's icon.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . The folder or program's icon will automatically be changed to your custom icon. If you ever want to go back to the old icon, simply go back to Properties > Customize or Shortcut > Change Icon… and click Restore Defaults at the bottom of the pop-up window.
